Body: Description: Actualmente contamos con el servicio de DLP en la empresa y esto debido a un crecimiento necesitamos instalar el EndPoint Protector en equipos que se encuentran en otra sucursal (segmentos de red diferentes), tengo entendido que para establecer esta comunicación el servidor necesita rutas estáticas para que la comunicación sea efectiva. Habrá manera de realizar esta configuración y también saber que requerimientos se necesitan de nuestro lado para realizar esta configuración.

What We've Learned Updated: Provided info: You can either use a Public IP for the EPP server(or a dns) and have the EPP clients to connect to that IP/dns, or you can use an internal IP. If you go on the internal IP route, then all the computers within your network should have the possibility to reach that IP, or have the possibility to use VPN and connect to it.
Next Steps Updated: Waiting on customer to confirm we can close this ticket.

Translation:

 

Regarding the options, I'll share some of my observations with you.

 

• Use a Public IP --- This option cannot be implemented as it poses a security risk to the company and the internal network.

• Use an Internal IP --- This option is already implemented in the company (computers on the same network segment have a connection).

• Use a VPN --- This option is already implemented as there is communication with other branches outside of Querétaro.

 

The idea is for computers on a different network (communication with other centers is through the VPN) to have the appropriate connection to the DLP server.

 

This configuration was previously in place, as they supported us at the time in this activity, but due to migration and backup issues, the configuration was lost.

 

Issue:

We currently have DLP services at our company, and due to growth, we need to install EndPoint Protector on devices located in different branches (different network segments). I understand that to establish this communication, the server needs static routes for effective communication. Is there a way to configure this, and I also need to know what requirements are needed on our side to configure it?

Next Steps Updated: Asked Eduard if he thinks there is another solution for this.
---
Waiting on customer to confirm we can close this ticket.

What We've Learned Updated: Proposed creating a route in their firewall. Alternative would be ssh access.

---
Provided info: You can either use a Public IP for the EPP server(or a dns) and have the EPP clients to connect to that IP/dns, or you can use an internal IP. If you go on the internal IP route, then all the computers within your network should have the possibility to reach that IP, or have the possibility to use VPN and connect to it.
